title: Stela of Amenemhat
section: Maintaining the Deceased in the Afterlife

museum_location.name: Funerary Gallery 2, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

rights_type.name: Creative Commons 3D

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.title: 37.1346E
labels.content: The four lines of hieroglyphic text at the top of this stela list what every Egyptian wanted in the afterlife: “thousands of portions of cattle, fowl, bread, alabaster, linen, and all kinds of green vegetables.” The inscription below mentions the name of the deceased, a man called Amunemhat, and his mother, Shabut. Amunemhat’s image appears just to the left of the offering table in the traditional place of honor. He was probably born in the reign of Amunemhat I and named for that king.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
